Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Archivist, librarian, historian, and editor. Chiefly correspondence relating to The Writings of George Washington edited by Fitzpatrick, together with card files indexing the work, drafts of speeches and of a study of Virginia colonial governors, and other papers and reference files.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Fitzpatrick, John Clement, 1876-1940, The writings of George Washington from the original manuscript sources, 1745-1799. 1931-1944.

corpname.part: Military Order of the Purple Heart.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of John Clement Fitzpatrick, archivist, librarian, historian, and editor, were given to the Library of Congress by Fitzpatrick's sister, Katherine F. Rodgers, in 1940. An addition was transferred from the Library of Congress Archives to the Manuscript Division in 1988.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed between 1968 and 1989. The finding aid was revised in 2012.

otherfindaid.head: Additional Guides
otherfindaid.p: An author and subject card index to Fitzpatrick's general correspondence prepared by Katherine Claggett, Fitzpatrick's secretary, is available in the Manuscript Division Reading Room.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of John Clement Fitzpatrick is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U. S. C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of John Clement Fitzpatrick are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, John Clement Fitzpatrick Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p:
The papers of John Clement Fitzpatrick (1876-1940) comprise four series spanning 1927-1940: General Correspondence , Correspondence with Sol Bloom , Miscellany , and Oversize . The bulk of the papers consists of correspondence dating between 1927 and 1941 centering on Fitzpatrick's service as editor of
The Writings of George Washington from the Original Manuscript Sources, 1745-1799
, prepared under the direction of the George Washington Bicentennial Commission. Included are letters concerning the location of original Washington documents to be published in the volumes and correspondence with the Government Printing Office relating to the printing of these volumes.

Because Fitzpatrick was widely regarded as an authority on George Washington, much of the
General Correspondence series concerns inquiries the editor received about Washington. The nationwide observance of the bicentennial of Washington's birth stimulated interest in every conceivable aspect of Washington's personal and public life. Fitzpatrick's replies to these wide-ranging questions are a valuable source of information on Washington. Various letters concern Washington's appearance and his dental problems, dentures, and dentist. There is also correspondence regarding the president's birthday, birthplace, death, burial, grave, and life mask, as well as other questions about his education and his ideas on education, his library, bookplate, sword, and the coat of arms and genealogy of the Washington family. Also included is a reply concerning a portrait of Mary Ball Washington, George Washington's mother, and considerable material on various portraits of Washington and Jean Antoine Houdon's bust of the president. Additionally, Fitzpatrick received many inquiries about the Washington "scandals," which he had attempted to refute in his pamphlet published in 1929. Washington's acts of charity, his religion and the so-called Washington's prayer, and his order against profanity are among other topics covered.

Fitzpatrick also received letters inquiring about Washington's surveys, travels, and writings, including among the latter his diaries, journals, account books, farewell address to the army, presidential farewell address, and both inaugural addresses. There is material relating to Mount Vernon, to Washington's marriage, including the date, place, and officiating minister, and to Washington's Masonic activities. There is also material relating to the origin of the Purple Heart award, correspondence about the papers of Washington's aide and friend, Tobias Lear, and answers to queries regarding the Declaration of Independence.

Sol Bloom , United States representative from New York, was vice chairman of the Washington Bicentennial Commission. There are letters to and from him in the General Correspondence series and also a separate series of his correspondence in connection with the commission. Bloom was interested in the observance of the sesquicentennial of the Constitution, and his correspondence contains a file, 1934-1938, concerning this project. William H. Richardson of New Jersey is also heavily represented in Fitzpatrick's General Correspondence . Richardson wrote extensively about the history of New Jersey during the American Revolution, Washington's activities in New Jersey, and the "Flying Camp." Also included in the collection is a file of mimeographed and printed matter that was sent to Fitzpatrick by Richardson.

Among the items in the Miscellany
are photostats of letters of most signers of the Constitution, drafts of and notes for speeches by Fitzpatrick, proofs of the index and illustrative material for
Writings of George Washington
, plates of illustrations for Fitzpatrick's
Aides and Secretaries to Gen. George Washington
, transcripts, notes and drafts relating to a study of Virginia colonial governors, miscellaneous newspaper clippings, and Oversize
photostats of amendments and proposed amendments to the Constitution.

In 1988 three card files maintained by Fitzpatrick were added to the collection. One file contains addresses of acquaintances, reference librarians, historical societies, book shops, publishers and editors, heads of history department, and historians. The second file is Fitzpatrick's working card index to his
Writings of George Washington
, and the third is a record of the material that he sent to the Government Printing Office for the publication of the
Writings
.

Correspondents in the General Correspondence series include Randolph Greenfield Adams, Maxwell Anderson, George A. Ball, Sol Bloom, Julian P. Boyd, Roy Bird Cook, Francis Pendleton Gaines, Curtis Wiswell Garrison, Louis F. Gottschalk, U. S. Grant (1881-1968), Alfred Bushnell Hart, Archibald Henderson, Rupert Hughes, J. Franklin Jameson, David Maydole Matteson, Samuel Eliot Morison, Elwin L. Page, Victor Hugo Paltsits, Josiah Harmar Penniman, William H. Richardson, James Alexander Robertson, Ernest Spofford, E. G. Swem, Alexander J. Wall, Charles Cecil Wall, Bernard Wolf Weinberger, and Henry Woodhouse.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in four series:

scopecontent.p:
Letters received and sent relating mainly to
Writings of George Washington
and questions and answers relating to all aspects of Washington's public and private life.

did.unittitle: 1927-1929 , including two letters of Winfield S. Hancock, 1866, 1873

scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Bloom on general topics and concerning the sesquicentennial of the Constitution.

Correspondence, draft writings, articles, notes, meeting minutes, printed matter, newspaper clippings, photostats, and miscellaneous material relating to New Jersey in the American revolution and to other Revolutionary War era topics, and to
Writings of George Washington
and other works by Fitzpatrick and others.

did.unittitle: Material from William H. Richardson, including article on the "Flying Camp," mimeographed and printed matter, and newspaper clippings relating to the revolution in New Jersey.

Printer's proofs of index to
Writings of George Washington

Illustrative material for
Writings of George Washington

Correspondence, minutes, and miscellaneous notes relating to the advisory committee on the
Writings of George Washington
; copies of lists of questions and answers regarding Washington compiled for Sol Bloom; list of Washington letters in various institutions; photostatic copies of letters of the signers of the Constitution (incomplete); photostat of a portrait of Washington by Edward Savage; notes and miscellaneous matter from Katherine Claggett, secretary to Fitzpatrick as editor of the
Writings of George Washington
.

Miscellaneous notes concerning Washington; notes on Haym Salomon; text of two speeches; notes on Theodore Roosevelt; engravings of portraits of Washington; copies of acts of Congress and other printed matter concerning the Washington Bicentennial Commission; galley proof of autobiography of Jonathan Boucher; other miscellany

Transcripts, edited drafts, and notes relating to a study of Virginia's colonial governors; plates of illustrations for Fitzpatrick's
Aides and Secretaries to Gen. George Washington

Photostats of ammendments and proposed ammendments to the Constitution
See Oversize

scopecontent.p: Photostats of amendments and proposed amendments to the Constitution and card indexes

arrangement.p: Arranged and described according to the containers and folders from which the material was removed.

did.unittitle: Photostats of amendments and proposed amendments to the Constitution, transferred from Sol Bloom's office (Container 23)

Index to
Writings of George Washington

Record of material sent to the Government Printing Office relating to
Writings of George Washington
